purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of tasks with the associated resources, the assignment of tasks to products and the grouping and ordering of tasks. The resource allocation, and the assignment to a product, may be qualified by a condition, a justification or a probability. Locations may be assigned to tasks and resources. A task is defined by a specification that provides the instructions for carrying out the work. The kinds of resources that may be defined for a task are:

ul.li: products, either types of product or individual products;
people, types of people, organizations, types of organization, or positions within organizations;
documents and information held as files.

purpose.p: Task specifications may be assigned to products, product breakdown elements, zones and interfaces. Conditions may be stated in terms of the state of the product, its age, its usage or any other parameter. Justifications can be related to supporting data or documents.
This module thereby enables the definition and exchange of a computer interpretable description of the work required to support a complex engineered asset throughout its service life.
The planning and scheduling of activities on individual products is out of scope.

inscope.li: the identification of resources required by tasks;
the identification of products to which tasks are assigned;
the association of properties with task specifications;
the association of dates, times, people, approvals and other management data with task specifications;
the specification of conditions under which a task falls due;
the association of a justification and a probability with a task assignment to a product, or a resource assignment to a task;
the association of a location with a task or resource.

outscope.li: work orders, work requests such as are used in preparing for actual work;
schemes, plans and schedules for performing sets of tasks.

uof.name: Task_specification_resourced
uof.description: The UOF enables the association of a task specification with the identification of resources necessary to carry out the task. It also enables the association of the task with the products on which the task is to be carried out.
